description.plain:
One of the greatest American rock bands were initially considered by many to be the pop fad side of grunge, but actually recorded numerous records (e.g. Siamese Dream, Adore, the sweeping Mellon Collie and the Infinite Sadness) that are among the most enduring and influential of the grunge era. Marked by the guitar virtuosity of Billy Corgan and lyrics that alternate between snarling fuck-off diatribes and tender introspection, Smashing Pumpkins were a four-piece force to be reckoned with.

Though featuring a variety of different members across a thirty year span, the original lineup included drummer Jimmy Chamberlin, guitarist James Iha and bassist D'arcy Wretzky.

description.plain:
“1979” is an homage to youth and all the pain, angst, and happiness that goes along with it.  With a fusion of alternative rock, new wave, and electronics, the Pumpkins stumbled upon an atmospheric sound that seemed to define a generation.  At the time of the release, this track sounded much different than anything the industry had ever heard before. “1979” was the last song recorded for Mellon Collie and the Infinite Sadness. Billy Corgan believed it belonged on the album, and after being told an earlier version of it wasn’t good enough, revamped it in about four hours, eventually to his producer’s approval.

The song is one of the band’s most popular and successful. Influential online magazine Pichfork ranked it as the 21st best song of the 1990s. In 2012 Rolling Stone readers voted it the second best Smashing Pumpkins song, with the publication calling it a “wistful pop hit.” The song was also nominated for Record of the Year and Best Rock Performance by a Group or Duo at the 39th Annual Grammy Awards, and its corresponding music video won “Best Alternative Video” at the 1996 MTV Music Video Awards.

songs.lyrics:
[Verse 1]
Shakedown 1979
Cool kids never have the time
On a live wire right up off the street
You and I should meet
Junebug skippin' like a stone
With the headlights pointed at the dawn
We were sure we'd never see an end
To it all

[Chorus]
And I don't even care
To shake these zipper blues
And we don't know
Just where our bones will rest
To dust I guess
Forgotten and absorbed
Into the earth below

[Verse 2]
Double-cross the vacant and the bored
They're not sure just what we have in store
Morphine city slippin' dues
Down to see

[Chorus 2]
That we don't even care
As restless as we are
We feel the pull
In the land of a thousand guilts
And poured cement
[Bridge]
Lamented and assured
To the lights and towns below
Faster than the speed of sound
Faster than we thought we'd go
Beneath the sound of hope

[Verse 3]
Justine never knew the rules
Hung down with the freaks and ghouls
No apologies ever need be made
I know you better than you fake it
To see

[Chorus 1]
That we don't even care
To shake these zipper blues
And we don't know
Just where our bones will rest
To dust I guess
Forgotten and absorbed
Into the earth below

[Outro]
The street heats the urgency of now
As you see there's no one around64EmbedShare URLCopyEmbedCopy

songs.full_title: Bullet with Butterfly Wings by The Smashing Pumpkins
songs.title: Bullet with Butterfly Wings

description.plain:
“Bullet with Butterfly Wings” won a GRAMMY in 1997 along with a slew of other awards.  It remains one of Smashing Pumpkins highest charting and most recognizable songs, being used in countless movies and television shows.

The song acted as the lead single off the sprawling, mega-successful album, Mellon Collie and the Infinite Sadness. It was not the band’s first pick as lead single however as  “Jellybelly” was actually supposed to take the slot.

During a making-of featurette for the video, Billy jokingly stated that the song was chosen as a single based on the results of a “survey of K-Mart shoppers between 30 and 40”.

“Bullet” has been sampled numerous times by a variety of artists. Notable artist Kid Cudi heavily sampled the track’s chorus in his 2018 hit, “The Rage” The song has also been parodied by both Bob Rivers in “Minimum Wage" and Weird Al Yankovic in “The Alternative Polka”.

The song evolved through numerous permutations during the recording process. One of the earliest demo recordings can be viewed here.

songs.full_title: Tonight, Tonight by The Smashing Pumpkins
songs.title: Tonight, Tonight

description.plain:
While Billy Corgan himself has revealed very little regarding the meaning behind the lyrics, the theme of “Tonight, Tonight” is one of hope.  To find the courage to lose oneself in the moment where all is possible.

The little information Corgan has given can be found in the 2012 liner notes:

Lyrically there were a few nods to Cheap Trick and Yeats, but the message I scrawled out was mine alone; rare in its direct honesty

In 1997, Corgan offered some commentary on the recording process:

When we were still in the middle of Siamese Dream touring, I booked us into a Chicago studio to just put all of our ideas down to tape. “Tonight” was one of those ideas…I never thought “Tonight, Tonight” would be a single. I just didn’t think people would get it. Also, I have to say that recording the 30-piece string section was probably one of the most exciting recording experiences I have ever had.

The music video was inspired by George Méliès' silent film A Trip to the Moon.  Méliès' name is actually written on a steamboat in the music video.



The video for “Tonight, Tonight” dominated the 1996 MTV VMA’s with 8 nominations and 6 wins.

songs.title: Today

description.plain:
Most listeners are surprised to learn that “Today” was written sarcastically. When reading the verses however, it becomes quite apparent. In Billy Corgan’s own words, he “was completely obsessed with killing [him]self”.

While “Today” actually describes the worst day possible, the song is still one of hope as it tells a tale of perseverance. When Corgan looks back at this song now, he sees it “as a positive song in that it’s about survival.”

songs.title: Disarm

description.plain:
The lyrics of “Disarm” touch upon the subject of child abuse as Billy Corgan directly addresses his parents in the first person as an abused son. However, during a performance in 2019, Corgan revealed “Disarm” is really about a time he contemplated suicide. He also revealed he wrote the song on the same day as “Today”, which he called his “suicidal anthem.” Thankfully, Corgan said he didn’t have the courage to kill himself and wrote the two songs instead.

Although Corgan is very capable of delivering angry vocals, “Disarm” has none, deliberately so.  Corgan told Rage in 1993:

I didn’t have the guts to kill my parents, so I thought I’d get back at them through song. And rather than have an angry, angry, angry violent song I’d thought I’d write something beautiful and make them realize what tender feelings I have in my heart, and make them feel really bad for treating me like shit

The instrumentation is dramatic, cinematic, and somewhat dark.  An acoustic guitar is strummed throughout but is often eclipsed by hopeful orchestral swells.

songs.title: Mayonaise

description.plain:
Billy Corgan’s explanation of the sound of his guitar in “Mayonaise”:

http://www.youtube.com/watch?v=5vd3uMxTpdI

In a 2012 interview with Adam Graham, Billy commented on his older music, specifically “Mayonaise”:

One that really jumps out is the song “Mayonaise,” which is kind of a treasured song by Pumpkins fans, off of ‘Siamese Dream.’ It was the last song I wrote lyrics for on the album. And it got to the point where it was like okay, I’ve gotta write these lyrics, I’ve gotta sing this song. And when I wrote it, I felt like I just threw together a bunch of weird one liners, basically. It didn’t feel like it had any synchronicity to me; I was just looking for good lines to sing. And now when I sing the song, I’m just shocked how closely reflective it is of what I was going through. It’s almost like this weird personal anthem to my experience, but I didn’t feel that at the time. And I can see why people identify with it, because now I identify with it. It’s hard to explain without going into long-winded answers, but just the direct narrative aspects of it really surprise me. It’s like how you can look at Picasso’s art and see who he was [sleeping with] at the time, you know. But instead of painting her, he paints Madonna. The Madonna, you know what I mean. He turns his mistress into the holy mother. Similar things happened with me. Stuff shows up in all these weird places, but I don’t remember thinking that at the time. I was just struggling for a language.

And while it is within the realm of possibility that the lyrics are more or less total bullshit and not connected in any way, the truth and pain Corgan is trying communicate with the audience comes out loud and clear, and there is without a doubt something brilliant about that. Though the song has for the most part, extremely vague lyrics and lines that may or may not have a place in them at all, it’s very easy to see that Billy Corgan is struggling with who he is, and that’s exactly why so many people can identify and relate to it.

Whether one is going thorough a nasty breakup, suffering the loss of a close friend or family member, or really just going through a rough patch, there is some truth to be found within the  heavy, distorted guitar and the anguish and passion in Billy Corgan’s voice.

songs.title: Zero

description.plain:
Zero was Corgan’s answer to the public’s perception of him as a Rock God and, simultaneously, a way to express his condition of apathy.  He expresses his reluctance to assume that role as he believes that such an indulgence can only lead to emptiness.

“Zero” became more than just a song to Billy Corgan; it became his alter-ego.

Zero is invincible.  After all, it is nothing to begin with. He removes his ego out of the tumultuous music scene he found himself submerged in.

The song shares its namesake with Billy’s iconic “ZERO” shirt. Billy wore a Superman/Superslut long-sleeve tee for much of the Siamese Dream tour, in effect mocking himself: though the world saw him as a rock idol and a super hero, he saw it as an archetypal cliche.  His solution was to declare to the public that he was worth nothing.

It is to say that ‘I’m not your god…

I’m your Zero .

songs.full_title: Cherub Rock by The Smashing Pumpkins
songs.title: Cherub Rock

description.plain:
In “Cherub Rock,” Corgan finds himself suddenly associated with a counter-culture that he never identified with or was included in. He accurately paints a picture of the volatile music industry at his time with his signature sarcasm intact.

Many musicians and artists are in it for the money and willfully jeopardize the integrity of their art. Corgan suggests fighting back against this notion in the name of fearless nonconformity.

In a 1995 interview, Corgan explained that every song on this album is about a personal relationship. “Cherub Rock,” Billy said, “is about my relationship to the indie-world and the media.”

songs.title: Soma

description.plain:
Loosely connected to the drug found in Huxley’s Brave New World, the song describes numbness as a defense mechanism to deal with life’s stresses.

Billy Corgan has commented that his inspiration came from the loss of a girlfriend in 1992:

It’s about the girlfriend who left me last year. I tried to put all my anger in those words, even though i’m just as much to blame for the break- up. “Soma” is based on the idea that a love relation is almost the same as opium: it slowly puts you to sleep, it soothes you, and gives you the illusion of sureness and security. Very deceiving.

songs.title: Thirty-Three

description.plain:
Although “Thirty Three” was the last single released, it was the first completed song off the Mellon Collie album, recorded and mastered immediately following the Siamese Dream Tour.

Corgan describes “Thirty-Three” as a “simple song in a country tuning.”  He goes on to describe exactly how this song came about:

I took three days off, and this was literally the first thing that came out of my hands when I sat down. I was living in my new house for the first time, and this song conveys all of that. The “cha-cha-cha” sound is my drum machine through a flanger, and what you hear is the same one right off the demo because I couldn’t remember how to recreate it. The stringy sounds are part Vocoder, plus five slide guitars tuned to one note each to create the chords.

The cover features a render of the face of Rasputin, a self-styled preacher in Russia who, thanks to his supposed healing powers on the heir to the throne, reached great heights of power during World War I, while the Tsar was away making pretend he was leading the army.

songs.full_title: Ava Adore by The Smashing Pumpkins
songs.title: Ava Adore

description.plain:
“Ava Adore” is the first single and the second song on The Smashing Pumpkins' fourth studio album Adore. Released May 18th, 1998, the track reached number 3 on the Billboard Top Alternative Songs and number 47 on the Billboard Hot 100 in 1998.

Released on June 1, 1998, the music video featured the band members clad in gothic ware, moving down a hallway as the camera steadily pans right to follow them. Although the focus remains on the band members, a revolving cast of strange characters and a sequence of contrasting sets continuously populate the background as well as the foreground.

When the camera reaches the endpoint of this hallway, it turns back to the left, revealing that the mesmerizing visuals the viewer had witnessed were illusions, as we can now see a film crew as well as all the equipment required to create such illusions.

The music video was awarded “Most Stylish Video” of the year at the 1998 VH! Fashion Awards.

songs.title: Hummer

description.plain:
One of the things that have defined the Smashing Pumpkins from the start was the way many of their songs will dynamically change from verse to verse, ending up almost like harmonious collages of many different ideas. Speaking to the Orlando Sentinel Tribune in 1992, guitarist James Iha detailed how they get there:

[The songs] mutate in 50,000 different directions. When we did the first album, songs would change over a few days, or change over months, but generally they always come out sounding very different when we’re through with them. We tend to play a song into the ground and just see what happens, make little changes here or there or scrap the whole song and keep one part.

“Hummer” is probably the most glaring example of this approach: aside from the first and third stanzas, no vocal melody or chord sequence is ever repeated in the verses; instead, the song moves from hook to hook, seamlessly navigating between distorted and quiet moments.

songs.title: X.Y.U.

description.plain:
“X.Y.U.” stands as one of the heaviest Pumpkins tracks, a grueling beast better experienced live. A fan favorite at concerts, as of 2019 it has been played live almost 300 times, often as an encore.

The screeching noise-rock textures and brutal metallic riffing which, while it is repetitive in a sense, undergoes a constant evolution to propel this harrowing standout to dizzying heights.

Just when the sonic machinery presents a downshift, the song takes off like a rocket ship with a sudden change in tempo when Corgan screams:

Into the eyes of the Jackal, I say, ‘KA-BOOM!’

James Iha, who spent a great deal of time recording “X.Y.U.,” found this song to be “disturbing:”

XYU is kind of a disturbing one though. It’s the monster inside of the band trying to get out!

As for the title, the alphabet usually ends with ‘Z’ of course. In the narrator’s twisted world however, it all ends with YOU.

Into the eyes of the Jackal, I say, ‘KA-BOOM!’

James Iha, who spent a great deal of time recording “X.Y.U.,” found this song to be “disturbing:”

XYU is kind of a disturbing one though. It’s the monster inside of the band trying to get out!

As for the title, the alphabet usually ends with ‘Z’ of course. In the narrator’s twisted world however, it all ends with YOU.

songs.title: Spaceboy

description.plain:
Billy Corgan wrote this song with his little brother Jesse as his inspiration. Jesse was born with mild cerebral palsy, Tourette’s syndrome, heart problems, and a chromosomal disorder.

“Spaceboy” deals with the frustration of feeling as though you don’t fit in.  Corgan can identify with his brother although he was born with no handicap.  In a 1994 interview, the Pumpkins frontman describes what he feels are similarities between him and his brother:

I feel our lives are similar…Freaks of nature, freaks of society, I always keep going back to something by Henry Miller. No matter how much he smiled, told jokes, shook hands, patted people on the back. People still looked at him funny, they still sensed something wasn’t right. I’ve always felt that way, that no matter how normal I appear, I was treated differently.

songs.title: Drown

description.plain:
Arguably one of the most famous non-singles that came out of 90’s alternative rock, “Drown” is a testament to the bold moves taken by Billy Corgan. While the song is often cited as one of the band’s strongest tracks, Corgan decided to release it on  the soundtrack of Cameron Crowe’s 1992 movie Singles instead of following the advice of managers and using it to further beef up the Siamese Dream album.

The song was written by Billy Corgan and recorded by The Smashing Pumpkins at Lenny Kravitz' famous Waterfront studio sometime during ‘91.
The track is a heavy mixture of alternative rock, psychedelia and dream pop. Despite the fact it was never released as a single (although the band fought for it to become one), it received heavy airplay in 1992.

According to Rolling Stone, “Drown” is considered by fans to be one of the Pumpkin’s best songs.

songs.title: Rhinoceros

description.plain:
“Rhinoceros” is the second single from the Pumpkins' debut album, Gish.  The song introduces listeners to that now familiar contrast, seesawing between soft and sweet to loud and abrasive.  This formula would later become a staple in 90’s era rock.

The song contains 17 separate tracks of feedback, foreshadowing the unique sound of Siamese Dream, achieved by the intricate guitar dubbing done executed by both Butch Vig and Billy Corgan.

It is arguably the first song that showed why the Pumpkins were a special breed. This track made it clear that the band was offering something truly unique when compared to the music coming from other rock bands in the early 1990’s, With an unusually slow tempo and a very dreamy quality to the guitar effects and vocal cadences. The song slowly comes alive in a way that could only be done by the Smashing Pumpkins.

songs.full_title: Here Is No Why by The Smashing Pumpkins
songs.title: Here Is No Why

description.plain:
The song’s title is reminiscent of Primo Levi’s Auschwitz memoir where, in response to the protagonist asking “Warum?” -“Why?”, a guard response “Hier ist kein warum” – “There is no why here.”

The title actually came from a tragedy and atrocity of equal proportion to that of Auschwitz.  Corgan explains in his 2012 reissue liner notes:

This title was appropriated from an article
I’d read on an anniversary of the world’s
first nuclear attacks. A survivor, in survey-
ing a legacy of near-total devastation, had remarked in broken English that ‘Here is
no why.’

songs.title: Galapogos

description.plain:
The song’s title comes from the Galápagos Islands, made famous by Charles Darwin.  Darwin’s observations on these islands led to the creation of the theory of evolution and his most famous work, On the Origins of Species.

With themes of innocence, both beautiful and naive, Corgan relates the concept of isolation found within his marriage to the isolation found in Darwin’s islands which inspired the theory of evolution.  Billy Corgan writes:

I cannot recall what it was about Darwin’s fabled set of islands that led me to associate my crumbling marriage to them.

songs.full_title: Mellon Collie and the Infinite Sadness by The Smashing Pumpkins
songs.title: Mellon Collie and the Infinite Sadness
songs.title_with_featured: Mellon Collie and the Infinite Sadness

description.plain:
This song began as an instrumental during the recording of Siamese Dream in Marietta, Georgia during the winter of 1992-1993. According to Butch Vig, Billy and drummer JImmy Chamberlin were playing the progression over and over during tracking one day. Having never heard the piece before, Butch eventually interrupted to ask what the song was. Billy responded that the song was called ‘Mellon Collie and the Infinite Sadness’. They recorded the version of the instrumental at the time, which was later released only on the vinyl edition of Mellon Collie (later as a bonus track on the Aeroplane Flies High reissue in 2013) as “Infinite Sadness”. This version is in a different key and has a wildly different, full-band arrangement.

Some time after moving into his Victorian house in Chicago, Billy re-arranged the song for piano. A clip of him playing this next version of the theme can be seen in the never-aired footage MTV shot sometime in 1995 for a making-of featurette, widely circulated online as the ‘666 Tapes’.

The theme makes a reprisal twice on the album – as a tag at the end of “Thru the Eyes of Ruby” in a different key (known as the ‘Nighttime Version’) and in an inverted form at the end of the album’s last track “Farewell and Goodnight”.

songs.full_title: Silvery Sometimes (Ghosts) by The Smashing Pumpkins
songs.title: Silvery Sometimes (Ghosts)

description.plain:
“Silvery Sometimes (Ghosts)” begins with multiple guitars playing rhythm and drives forward with a strong vocal melody from frontman Corgan. The song continues with more guitars and a strong chorus, reminiscent of classic Pumpkins tracks. Multiple critical reviews including Rolling Stone compared the general vibe of the song to “1979,” a classic track from 1995’s Mellon Collie and the Infinite Sadness.

The Rick Rubin produced track was released September 13, 2018 as the second single for the band’s 10th studio album, SHINY AND OH SO BRIGHT, VOL. 1.  The song is the first Pumpkins track to hit the Billboard Alternative airplay chart since 2012’s “The Celestials”.

The music video, directed by Corgan, features Mark McGrath of legendary rock band Sugar Ray. The video follows the band members as they embark on a charity challenge requiring them to stay the night in a reportedly haunted house.

songs.title: Muzzle

description.plain:
“Muzzle” is the twelfth song on the first disc, Dawn to Dusk, of The Smashing Pumpkins' third album, and first and only double album, Mellon Collie and the Infinite Sadness.

Lyricist and lead singer Billy Corgan has said that this song was written partially as a preemptive strike on critics who were going to listen to Mellon Collie and tell Billy to “shut up."

songs.full_title: Geek U.S.A. by The Smashing Pumpkins
songs.title: Geek U.S.A.

description.plain:
“Geek U.S.A.” is frequently praised by fans and critics alike for its complexity. For example, a 1993 review in The New York Times stated:

With the […] Hendrix pyrotechnics of ‘Geek U.S.A.,’ the Pumpkins aim for grandeur.

The studio version contains close to 30 overdubbed guitars, creating a lush symphony of distorted tones, each with their own distinctive sound. As the song slows down and transitions into a dreamy interlude, Billy Corgan’s voice softens to a hush as drummer Jimmy Chamberlin effortlessly matches the dynamic with his percussion work.

Corgan takes the song to new heights with a solo that would later be ranked at #54 in Guitar World magazine’s reader poll of the “Greatest Guitar Solos of All Time.” In a September 1994 issue of Guitar Player magazine, Billy said:

The solo on ‘Geek USA’ completely jacks up the song. It’s not there because I wanted to play a solo, but because the song needed to kick up another notch.

annotatable.link_title: Geek U.S.A. by The Smashing Pumpkins
annotatable.title: Geek U.S.A.

body.plain:
“Geek U.S.A.” is frequently praised by fans and critics alike for its complexity. For example, a 1993 review in The New York Times stated:

With the […] Hendrix pyrotechnics of ‘Geek U.S.A.,’ the Pumpkins aim for grandeur.

The studio version contains close to 30 overdubbed guitars, creating a lush symphony of distorted tones, each with their own distinctive sound. As the song slows down and transitions into a dreamy interlude, Billy Corgan’s voice softens to a hush as drummer Jimmy Chamberlin effortlessly matches the dynamic with his percussion work.

Corgan takes the song to new heights with a solo that would later be ranked at #54 in Guitar World magazine’s reader poll of the “Greatest Guitar Solos of All Time.” In a September 1994 issue of Guitar Player magazine, Billy said:

The solo on ‘Geek USA’ completely jacks up the song. It’s not there because I wanted to play a solo, but because the song needed to kick up another notch.

songs.title: Quiet

description.plain:
Siamese Dream is an undeniably personal album for songwriter Billy Corgan.  As he puts it, every song is about some sort of relationship.  “Quiet,” a song about his relationship with his parents, is harsh in its condemnations yet may be the most intimate on the album.

The track drives hard and is yet another example of the Pumpkins' guitar virtuosity.  Low-end guitars overdubbed and timed with machine-like intricacy drives the sound like a train.  Screeching high frequencies come from, again, a slew of overdubbed guitars, yet with tones that contrast greatly with those playing the low notes which dominate.

songs.title: Rocket

description.plain:
The fourth and final single off Siamese Dream, featuring the band’s trademark “guitar wall” sound. This was the first song written for Siamese Dream.

The music video for “Rocket” was the first Pumpkins collaboration with directors Jonathan Dayton and Valerie Faris. The same duo would go on to direct the iconic videos for “1979” and “Tonight, Tonight”, which won a total of seven combined awards at the 1996 MTV Video Music Awards and cemented the Pumpkins as the most decorated act of that year.

Aided by the notoriety of these works, Dayton and Faris would go on to have a career in Hollywood, directing films such as Little Miss Sunshine.

songs.title: Solara

description.plain:
First released on June 8, 2018, “Solara” is the first Smashing Pumpkins song in 18 years featuring three quarters or the band’s original lineup (frontman  Billy Corgan, guitarist James Iha, and drummer Jimmy Chamberlin). The only original Pumpkins member not on the track is bassist D'Arcy, who conceded a well-publicized interview slamming Corgan and the band at the time the reunion rumors began surfacing.

The song was first spoken of by Corgan on March 27th of 2014 in the context of being a possible addition to the tracklist of their previous album, Monuments to an Elegy. It wasn’t until drummer Jimmy Chamberlin rejoined the band and put his special brand of percussive treatment to the track that “Solara” was album ready. As Corgan put it, “We always thought the song was strong, but we couldn’t find the magic in it…The minute we put it in Jimmy Chamberlin’s hands, it’s like, ‘Oh, there’s the magic.’

The track was produced by Rick Rubin, who had worked with the band before on the Adore outtake “Let Me Give the World to You”. Rubin also produced Corgan’s second solo album, Ogilala.

songs.title: Bodies

description.plain:
Love is suicide.

Courtney Love, lead singer of Hole and rocker boy heartbreaker, having been in relationships with Kurt Cobain, Trent Reznor, and lead singer of The Smashing Pumpkins Billy Corgan, says the hit songs Corgan wrote are about her. Although these claims seem to be elicited for attention by Love, it makes sense given the chorus lyric.

Love is suicide.

songs.full_title: Stand Inside Your Love by The Smashing Pumpkins
songs.title: Stand Inside Your Love

description.plain:
“Stand Inside Your Love” is the lead single from the Smashing Pumpkins' final studio album before their initial breakup.

As Corgan explained on VH1 Storytellers in August of 2000. “Stand Inside Your Love” was  written and arranged very quickly and evolved into a classic Pumpkins song within a day.

[The song] mutated into classic Smashing Pumpkins in that it sounds as if it could have come from any [Pumpkins] album."

After nailing down the musical arrangement, Corgan realized he had no vocals or even an idea for a vocal melody.

I woke up the next morning and I was reading a book.  I had the words, ‘Who wouldn’t stand inside your love’ in my head and I didn’t know what it meant….it’s the strangest feeling, its like a faucet opens up in my head and suddenly I understand the whole song; I see it all.  The lyrics were written in ten minutes and I still have the sheet of paper.  Not one word is different.

The official music video is described as an homage to Oscar Wilde’s Salomé and stars the film director and photographer, Yelena Yemchuk, who was also Corgan’s girlfriend at the time.

songs.full_title: Fuck You (An Ode to No One) by The Smashing Pumpkins
songs.title: Fuck You (An Ode to No One)
songs.title_with_featured: Fuck You (An Ode to No One)

description.plain:
This song was referred to as “An Ode to No One” on the original packaging, but recent reissues have reverted back to the song’s original title, “Fuck You (An Ode to No One).”

When asked who this song is directed towards, Frontman Billy Corgan told Rolling Stone in 1995:

The basic thing is just fuck everybody. It’s that feeling where no one understands: ‘Who the fuck are my friends? Fuck you. Fuck everybody. Fuck everything.’ It’s just that thought – pure frustration.

And indeed, the angst-ridden, monstrous ‘Fuck You’ is just as its title suggests.

songs.full_title: Cupid de Locke by The Smashing Pumpkins
songs.title: Cupid de Locke

description.plain:
“Cupid de Locke” is a reference to Matthew Locke, an English Baroque composer during the 17th century who wrote the score to a masque entitled Cupid and Death, which is a story about Cupid and Death getting their arrows mixed up thus causing great distress and humor to ensue.



The song’s instrumentation, led by synthetic harp arpeggios and household items as percussion, is one of Mellon Collie’s biggest departures from the classic Pumpkins sound.

songs.title: Eye

description.plain:
This genre-bending track gave fans one of the first glimpses into the new direction the band was heading while rumors swirled regarding what the future held for the Smashing Pumpkins.

Released at the height of Smashing Pumpkins fame, “Eye” give us a taste of a genre that was struggling to find a place in the 1990’s.  Mixing electronica and alternative rock, we get a very interesting sound that has been further developed in popular music extensively since.

Soon after this song was released, the Pumpkins continued working these new electronic rock arrangements with songs such as “Ava Adore” and “The Beginning is the End is the Beginning”.

The song began life as a collaboration between Billy Corgan and Shaquelle O'Neal that went nowhere. When David Lynch and Nine Inch Nails frontman Trent Reznor were assembling the soundtrack for the film, Lost Highway, they asked Billy to submit a song.
Corgan originally submitted the song Tear, but that was rejected and later reworked to appear on the Smashing Pumpkins album Adore. Corgan dusted this off, reworked it a bit, and gave it to Lynch, who loved the track and placed it during a Night Club scene in the film.

songs.title: Love

description.plain:
Buzzing with multiple and unique guitar tones and anamorphic vocal effects, “Love” plays as if the song has declared war on its subject.  Corgan plows through a soundscape that feels deceptive, singing  piercingly sincere vocals in what seems like a conscious attack on romantic love.

Indeed, these nihilistic tones seem to often undermine the hopeful idealism throughout Melon Collie as a whole.  “Tonight, Tonight,”, arguably the most hopeful song found on the album, still contains at least one line hinting at the loss of innocence:  “The more you change the less you feel.”

“Love” is described in the liner notes below first as the type of love “wherever sex is applied as cause and effect” and later as “an unrelenting god that won’t let go until you are spent.”  Indeed, love can be dubious and clever in the worst kind of way.

In a revealing 1998 interview with Switch Magazine, songwriter Billy Corgan was asked first what sex meant to him:  “It doesn’t interest me, I can reject it.”  He was then asked what love meant to him:  “I don’t reject love. Love is what you are, love is suicide.”

songs.full_title: The Beginning Is the End Is the Beginning by The Smashing Pumpkins
songs.title: The Beginning Is the End Is the Beginning
songs.title_with_featured: The Beginning Is the End Is the Beginning

description.plain:
“The Beginning Is The End Is The Beginning” is track 15 from the Batman & Robin Sountrack.

It is an alternate version of the album’s opening track and lead single: “The End Is The Beginning Is The End”, featuring a different instrumentation (slow keyboards instead of fist-pumping guitars) and new lyrics for the verses & bridge. This version of the song became more popular following it’s use in trailers for Zack Snyder’s 2009 film Watchmen (to the surprise of Billy Corgan, who considered it “a version of that song that never seemed to get any notice.”)
https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=LeWllu-Qam4

description.plain: “Thru the Eyes of Ruby” is about Corgan’s soon to be (at the time) ex-wife Chris Fabian. Many of the songs off Mellon Collie were about Fabian and how Corgan wanted to break free from her. He was sure the feeling was mutual, and this song is about convincing her so.

songs.full_title: Farewell and Goodnight by The Smashing Pumpkins
songs.title: Farewell and Goodnight

description.plain:
The final track on the whole of Mellon Collie, “Farewell and Goodnight” features all the band members on vocals, gathered together for a message of unity that plays out like a lullaby.

This is the only song in existence of which drummer Jimmy Chamberlin sings on. According to the album’s liner notes, he reportedly loved the idea until he stepped in front of the microphone.

songs.full_title: To Sheila by The Smashing Pumpkins
songs.title: To Sheila

description.plain:
The opening track on the Smashing Pumpkins' fourth studio LP, Adore, prepares listeners for a dramatic break from the past. “To Sheila” greets fans with nothing but a quietly picked acoustic guitar and Corgan’s subdued vocals before an accentuating yet minimal drum sequence is introduced, causing the song to take on a ghostly presence.

The song has been mentioned as a standout track by many music critics, frequently in reference to the poetic lyrics. Corgan describes it as “a veiled love song [that] also talks about the idea that all we really seek in life is to truly feel alive.”

Today, “To Sheila” is a recognizable fan favorite that has, like many of Corgan’s creations, undergone quite a few transformations. The newest arrangement of the song was introduced during the Ogilala tour and can be viewed below.

  


https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=3kRcn-6wdl4

songs.title: Jellybelly

description.plain:
The choice to place a song like “Jellybelly” so early in the tracklist definitely makes a statement. The band seems to be communicating that, although  “Tonight, Tonight” kicks it off, this is not a positive album full of hope. This is an unflinching journey into the human condition.

After all, “Jellybelly” is arguably the heaviest track on the album (the contender being “Tales of a Scorched Earth”). With multiple guitars swirling around an unpredictable drum sequence, it closely resembles something more akin to heavy metal than to what most consider alternative rock. It does reign in the chaos for a more melodic and ordered chorus however, giving it an accessibility not normally found in harder songs that stray into the metal genre

When pushed to pick a first single for the album, Corgan originally chose “Jellybelly.”  As he explained to Alternative Nation, his initial first choice was based on his rebellious nature:

‘Bullet’ was the absolute obvious choice…which is kind of why I didn’t want it to be the first single. You know, in Pumpkinland, we don’t really like to do the obvious thing. I felt really close to ‘Jellybelly,’ because it sounds to me like a classic Pumpkins song from a third album.

songs.full_title: Porcelina of the Vast Oceans by The Smashing Pumpkins
songs.title: Porcelina of the Vast Oceans

description.plain:
The elusive lover, Porcelina, beckons the subject to the edge of belief and beyond.  His belief system changes as he gives into Porcelina and gazes past “The realm of soft delusions.”

Ordinarily we put up mental blocks as a defense mechanism in order to stay within the fragile framework that supports our belief system.  Corgan refers to this defense mechanism as “the thought police” in these lyrics and suggests that the power of Porcelina is causing them to shut down.

Porcelina is now free to take the narrator as far as she wishes, past his preconceived notions and into a deeper realm of thought.



Many have been inspired by this particular song.  This is one of many pieces of fan art dedicated to "Porcelina"

songs.full_title: By Starlight by The Smashing Pumpkins
songs.title: By Starlight

description.plain:
This is one of the several songs about Corgan’s marriage with Chris Fabian, which ended bitterly shortly after the release of Mellon Collie.

An on-again, off-again couple, they decided to get married after having been separated for a time. The separation was the impetus for Siamese Dream’s “Soma”.

Like the wedding itself, the song begins hopeful and wide-eyed, only for the chorus to describe the coldness they ended up feeling for each other.

While Corgan has always been reticent about his marriage, according to his Confessions he had immediately suspected that the wedding might have been merely a stogpap in their failing relationship:

(…) standing out here on the top porch, me looking at the dim stars, and her asleep inside, I realize nothing had really changed at all.

songs.title: Stumbleine

description.plain:
A song full of single-sentence stories, “Stumbeline” speaks of swapping roles in a relationship in order to deal with the burdening problems that plague the world.

The characters in the mini stories, perhaps connected, seem to be caught in the difficulties of youth: problems with parents, drugs, loneliness, disillusion. Pretty much the main themes around which Mellon Collie turns.

Corgan has stated that “Stumbleine” is a woman’s name, and fans have also speculated that it is derived from the Shakespearean play Cymbeline, also known as “The Injur’d Princess”; others claim the inspiration came from Hans Christian Andersen’s fairy tale “Thumbelina”, although it might just be word play with the word “stumbling”.

Musically, Corgan has said in a 1996 interview that it is:

a demo that I recorded at my house. I play my Ovation acoustic on that one. What’s unusual about that riff is that the octaves are played on A and B strings, with the open D and G strings ringing in between the octaves.

songs.title: Landslide

description.plain:
This is a cover of a Fleetwood Mac song which was originally written by Stevie Nicks. According to Stevie, she wrote it during a time when she did not know whether to return to study or continue recording professionally with her partner.

Notes on the recording from the liner notes of Pisces Iscariot:

Landslide is a stevie nicks song. I fell in love with this song and forced myself to learn it because i’m very bad at figuring out songs by other people. of course I learned it totally the wrong way and after it was recorded jimmy from the frogs showed me the easier way to play it. this song is very revelant to my life at the moment still, and that is why i love to sing it. LANDSLIDE – was recorded at the BBC, not my most favourite place to record. They are still in 1971 but todd the producer man was very nice. the recording is way too hissy and we’re sorry but it is the fault of the BBC, whose financial raping of us to use this song and sandoz almost didn’t make putting these songs out possible, but it is here.

In the 2012 reissue, these additional notes were added:

By the time I got around to recording this I had only 20 minutes left… I did rhythms in one take playing a solo without knowing what key the song is to the track barren with vocal. I sang two takes, listening back in the control room and summarily declaring ‘use the front half of take one and the second half of take two,’ before walking out the door… I was shocked when this song became a hit, a success not supported by a video.

songs.full_title: Take Me Down by The Smashing Pumpkins
songs.title: Take Me Down

description.plain:
The final track of the first half of Mellon Collie and the Infinite Sadness (Dawn to Dusk ), “Take Me Down” features guitarist James Iha on vocals instead of Billy Corgan.

The meaning of the song can be interpreted in a couple different ways. The narrator may be beckoning another to join them in their life. Other lyrics suggest they may be returning to a familiar and comfortable place after being exposed to the blistering weather of the world.

This particular song plays a large part in Pumpkins history. As described in Billy Corgan’s liner notes found below, James Iha’s involvement with this album and his relationship with the band itself found a turning point in the development of this track.

songs.full_title: Lily (My One and Only) by The Smashing Pumpkins
songs.title: Lily (My One and Only)

description.plain:
In this humorous story of voyeurism, the narrator tells of his unhealthy obsession with a woman named Lily.  As the song progresses, it becomes clear that this is not your typical love song.  He watches her window through his vantage point, perched on a tree.

He’s finally arrested and taken to jail when someone (presumably Lily herself) calls the police.

songs.full_title: Where Boys Fear to Tread by The Smashing Pumpkins
songs.title: Where Boys Fear to Tread

description.plain:
While Courtney Love does indeed claim “Where Boys Fear to Tread” was inspired by her, Corgan hasn’t commented on the issue.  This isn’t unusual however, as Corgan rarely explains his lyrics and tries to stay away from tabloid fame.

According to Love, the song is about her and Trent Reznor of Nine Inch Nails.  Love claims that Corgan, Love’s ex-boyfriend, was angry when he found out Reznor and Love were in a relationship and this song is the product of that distress.  Upon objective inspection, the lyrics seem to tell a different story however.  While “For a love lost, a faded picture” seems to allude to an ex-lover, the lyric is also very ambiguous.

In the end, nobody but Corgan can take credit for this angst-ridden track.  It would be quite a stretch to claim that songs such as these, which have survived in spirit for decades, were only possible because of Courtney Love.  Nobody challenges the fact that Corgan both wrote and executed the lyrics and instrumentation after all (except for the drums of course, we have Jimmy Chamberlain to thank for that).

songs.title: Siva

description.plain:
One of the harder tracks from the album, “Siva” was surprisingly written and demoed on an acoustic guitar. “Siva” is most easily recognized from the opening guitar riff, one that writer/composer Billy Corgan compares aesthetically to Led Zeppelin’s power riff on “Whole Lotta Love”.

‘Siva’ had one of those riffs that let me know immediately that I had a song, even though I had yet to work out all the parts. James Iha adds to the riff by playing a contrasting sequence. That riff sounded like my band–it had instant identity–and it got my blood going right away. There was something about it that was so distinctive that it made a lot of other songs I’d written seem wimpy and weak by comparison. Since then, I’ve always tried to find that weird marriage of a great riff. The “Siva” riff crystallized everything I was trying to do with the band. It had power and immediacy, and the song seemed to write itself around the riff.

Billy has described Gish as a very spiritual album. Corgan originally titled the song “Shiva”, referring to the Tantric concepts of Shiva and Shakti as opposing masculine and feminine forces, ignorant of any further implications of the name (although he is now well read on the subjects of Eastern religions and philosophies). Upon realizing that the name was more readily connected with the Hindu god Shiva, he removed the letter “h” from the title to lessen this association.

songs.full_title: The Everlasting Gaze by The Smashing Pumpkins
songs.title: The Everlasting Gaze

description.plain:
Both the lead single and opening track for Machina, “The Everlasting Gaze” was released on December 9, 1999, complete with a music video directed by the Grammy award-winning artist, Jonas Åkerlund.  The video gave us the first glimpse of the new band line-up, bringing back drummer Jimmy Chamberlin and replacing D'arcy Wretzky with former Hole bandmate Melissa Auf der Maur as the bassist.



Musically, this has a very similar sound to “Zero”.  Not only are the effects on the lead guitar nearly identical, but the primary guitar riff itself is very similar.  Both songs use a lot of the same notes and the guitar sequences are compressed into roughly one bar.  “The Everlasting Gaze” however alternates between one bar of guitar and one of drums and vocals, an effective formula used mostly in the blues genre.  In contrast, “Zero” plays the guitar riff continuously.

Both songs also have a moment in the second verse where all instrumentation comes to a sudden halt while Corgan executes one of his famous vocal rants.  The lyrics from this particular moment in “Zero” are now quite famous:

Emptiness is loneliness
And loneliness is cleanliness
And cleanliness is Godliness
So God is empty
Just like me"

The similarities to “Zero” are quite fitting given this album introduces the listener to a character named Zero.  This alter-ego Corgan speaks through is, in essence, a hyperbolic personification of his own public persona.  Just as other artists such as David Bowie and Eminem have done, he created a cartoonish version of himself that he can use to interact with both the media and the public.



Billy Corgan wrote and composed the track.  Regarding the overall meaning, he told the the Chicago Sun-Times on April of 2000:

[It] has a lot to do with spirituality and trying to find my place in the universe and sort of humbly accepting limitations and the things I’ve been graced with. It’s more of a humanistic world view. I’m not writing anymore for the tortured teen…I’m writing with the idea that everybody’s experiencing these things all the time, and even if they’re not experiencing them personally, they’re affected by them. You can live in the street and write about the garbage, or you can try to get up a little higher and look down and try to see the bigger picture.

songs.full_title: The End Is the Beginning Is the End by The Smashing Pumpkins
songs.title: The End Is the Beginning Is the End
songs.title_with_featured: The End Is the Beginning Is the End

description.plain:
This song was written by Billy Corgan for the Batman & Robin soundtrack and prepared fans for the new direction the Pumpkins were headed, culminating on the critically acclaimed Adore LP.

The lyrics are a representation of the Batman of the 1940’s when he was a “darker character”.  Soon after the release of the single, Corgan spoke to MTV about his decision to create a song for a character like Batman.

At one point I found myself going, “I can’t write a song about Batman, I’m in an alternative band.” And I thought this is stupid, if I can write a song about Batman and it serves the purpose, which is to make it happen and connect with the movie, and connect with something that is unique and original, then, why not?



The lyrics, instrumentation and music video are all a testament to the vision of the darker side of Batman.  Press the play button to watch the highly stylized music video nominated for four awards at the 1997 MTV VMAs.

songs.title: Beautiful

description.plain: Every band has to have that one song that has no other meaning than pure love. “Beautiful” is as simple as its title: It’s about just love. Love, in a grungy, introspective, pessimistic way, but nevertheless love.

body.plain: Every band has to have that one song that has no other meaning than pure love. “Beautiful” is as simple as its title: It’s about just love. Love, in a grungy, introspective, pessimistic way, but nevertheless love.

songs.full_title: Try, Try, Try by The Smashing Pumpkins
songs.title: Try, Try, Try

description.plain:
“Try, Try, Try” was the third and final single from the band’s fifth studio album, Machina/The Machines of God, and was released on September 11, 2000. It was written by Billy Corgan, as was the B-side “Here’s to the Atom Bomb”.

An alternate version of “Try, Try, Try” appears on the third EP of the album Machina II/The Friends & Enemies of Modern Music and the “Untitled” single. The alternate version is a more sparse version of the song, orchestrated on acoustic guitar with a repeating keyboard part, as opposed to the piano, synth, and electric guitar-heavy Machina version.

songs.full_title: I Am One by The Smashing Pumpkins
songs.title: I Am One

description.plain:
The Smashing Pumpkins' first official release was the “I Am One” single, originally recorded in 1989 and released in 1990 on 7" vinyl (only 1500 copies were pressed and now sell for approximately $175 USD). The single also contains “Not Worth Asking”, the first of many B-sides the band would put out.

“I Am One” was later chosen to be the opening track of the band’s 1991 debut album, Gish. The music video was shot in 1990, but as the band was unhappy with it, the video wasn’t released until 2001 on a compilation DVD.

Live performances of “I Am One” – such as the one featured on the Viewphoria DVD –  include an art-break or rant, in which Corgan improvises, sometimes using verses from other songs – such as “Zero.”

 Pictured above is the original Limited Potential release

songs.full_title: Sweet Sweet by The Smashing Pumpkins
songs.title: Sweet Sweet

description.plain:
Coming in right after the heavy nine minute “Silverfuck”, the song begins with a clean chorus-set guitar, then followed by a slightly distorted guitar in the same tune as the clean guitar. A shaker then joins after a couple seconds of guitar. Then Billy’s soothing voice joins in. It’s a perfect song, even for a minute.

In 2017, the song was played for the first time in 23 years.

songs.full_title: For Martha by The Smashing Pumpkins
songs.title: For Martha

description.plain:
“For Martha” is a tribute to Corgan’s mother, Martha Louise.  Martha died of cancer while Corgan was in the midst of a world tour supporting Mellon Collie and the Infinite Sadness in 1996.

Corgan briefly mentions the making of this track in his blog. Incredibly, this eight minute song (with all its complexities) was primarily recorded as one live take with Matt Cameron of Soundgarden and Pearl Jam stepping in for Jimmy Chamberlin on drums.

songs.full_title: Tales of a Scorched Earth by The Smashing Pumpkins
songs.title: Tales of a Scorched Earth

description.plain:
This song is about Corgan’s continuous struggle with apathy; or, in his own words, about “teenage nihilism”.

According to him:

When I recorded the song, I had mixed feelings about putting it on the album, but when I just got away from the intellectualizing and just listened to it, I enjoyed it. It’s total bombast. Within the context of the whole record, it fits nicely.

songs.title: Cyr

description.plain:
“Cyr” is one half of the double A-side single speculated to appear on part two of the Shiny and Oh So Bright series. The name of the song comes from old Greek meaning “King” or “Leader.”

The song is strongly influenced by new wave and electronica. Multiple synthesizers, a steady EDM tempo held in place by the thud of a classic House kick, subtle guitar work, and layered dance vocals which sit front and center of the mix deliver a very unique aesthetic given the Pumpkin’s history.

The background vocals, performed by Sierra Swan and Katie Cole (both of whom have worked with Corgan in the past), are also very present in the mix. Swan and Cole serve  more a purpose than to parrot Corgan. The singers add a heavy ambience to the track with with vocal swells and reverse reverb production effects which Corgan, who also produced the track, makes use of.

songs.title: Snail

description.plain:
The seventh track off the Pumpkins' debut album, “Snail” is a prime exemple of the marriage of beautiful melodies and heavy distortion that set the Pumpkins apart from the get go. It is an early pick of Corgan’s as his favorite Pumpkins song:

[P]robably the song the consistently stays with me is ‘Snail’. Because it’s a song that wasn’t one of those songs [that] when you play it you say, ‘hey this is a really great song’. We had to work on it and work on it, and kept it in my mind, and kept thinking about it.

songs.title: Daydream

description.plain:
Recorded in 1989, “Daydream” was first featured in the original Smashing Pumpkins Demo tape, later released under the music label, Chance.

Two versions of “Daydream” were recorded, one of which featured Corgan on vocals (it has since been released as a B-Side). For this LP however, Pumpkins bassist, D'arcy Wretsky, takes the microphone. Corgan wrote that “[D'arcy’s] voice is prettier, more cold, and far away.” This is the first (but not the last) time Ms. Wretsky graces a Pumpkins vocal track, although one can count these instances on one hand.

This song features a hidden track called “I’m Going Crazy”, starting around the 2:00 mark.

songs.title: Crush

description.plain:
“Crush” is a rare song for the Pumpkins in that it celebrates love.  Minimal percussion supports a slow bass line, starting low and walking up to meet a psychedelic guitar which sets the tone for this track.

As Corgan states in the liner notes, he wrote this song about his then future wife, Christine Fabian.  He wrote it in the middle of the night in her apartment as she was sleeping.

He seems to be pondering whether he can contest the love he feels for her.  After all, he was taught at a very young age to distrust love.  Even in this romantic song, there are shades of pessimism to be found within.

songs.full_title: Bury Me by The Smashing Pumpkins
songs.title: Bury Me

description.plain:
While one can infer all sorts of meanings from these lines, not even the writer knows what to make of them.  After all, the song was written at least two years before it was released.

“Bury Me” is a heavy guitar rock groover, big on riffs yet progressive. D'arcy’s relentless heavy bass rhythm kicks things off before drummer Jimmy Chamberlin leads the way.  The guitars, while following the dynamic structure already set forth, seem to have a life of their own.

Guitar solos (and heavy rock in general) were anything but trendy in 1991.  It wasn’t until the grunge movement gained momentum that guitar solos began to see a comeback.  That being said, the two separate guitar solos found here are a testament to both the uniqueness of the band as well as their defiant nature.

As the song progresses, we hear a slew of separate guitar tones, all overdubbed on top of one another, similar to what the band would later create in their major label debut, Siamese Dream.

songs.full_title: Blew Away by The Smashing Pumpkins
songs.title: Blew Away

description.plain:
Originally released as a B-side to the “Disarm” single, “Blew Away” speaks of love and devotion.  Written and produced by Pumpkins guitarist James Iha, this track is one of the first songs Iha contributed lead vocals to.

“Blew Away” holds the distinction of being one of the only early Pumpkins songs that does not feature Jimmy Chamberlin on drums.  Instead, co-producer and ex-husband to bassist D'arcy Wretzky, Kerry Brown stepped in while Chamberlin was on vacation.  Brown was also the drummer for Pumpkins contemporaries Catherine. He has also assisted in the production, mixing, and recording of many Pumpkins songs and demos throughout the years..

Perhaps contrary to expectations the guitar solo found in the song is performed by Billy Corgan rather than Iha.

songs.title: Crestfallen

description.plain:
Crestfallen was to be the third single from Adore but was only released as a promotional single due to a strained relationship with the band’s label, Virgin Records. While it did play on various radio stations in the United States, it never made the Billboard charts.  Billboard did review the song, praising and criticizing it at the same time.

The instrumentation is dominated by Billy Corgan’s piano composition, accented by a minimalist approach on the guitar composed by Billy Corgan and played by James Iha.  All the other instrumentation is electronic, a great example of Adore’s departure from guitar-heavy rock music.

The bold move of this drastic change in style resulted in some initial disappointment among many fans.  Ultimately, this new direction proved to display another dimension to the band, showcasing their diversity.  Many fans now cite Adore as their favorite work by the Pumpkins.



One of the many pieces of Adore fan art

Lyrically, this song primarily revolves around a question: “Who am I to need you when I’m down?”  Corgan had this to say when asked about the lyrics to “Crestfallen”:

My mother’s death helped me to refocus my priorities. It showed me the true value of my life.

songs.full_title: Blank Page by The Smashing Pumpkins
songs.title: Blank Page

description.plain:
Originally named “48 Chords” as a commentary on the unusual high number of piano chords played, “Blank Page” is about Corgans marriage ending. According to himself, he felt it was odd he had not written about it earlier, but only with this song could express how he felt about it.

Save for “17,” which isn’t really a song at all, “Blank Page” closes the Adore as quietly as it opened, although with a more somber ambiance, giving the listener the feeling that after all the meditations on loss, nothing has been solved.

description.plain:
“17,” a 17 second instrumental, closes the album much like it began: soft, subdued, and subtle. The back of the album pamphlet contains a poem written by Billy Corgan also entitled “17” and is  featured on this page as “lyrics”.

Corgan later revealed in the liner notes for the 2014 deluxe reissue of Adore that this slot was originally reserved for “Blissed and Gone,” a song that wouldn’t see the light of day for three more years before being released on the B-Side compilation disc, Judas 0.

songs.title: Suffer

description.plain:
“Suffer” was originally titled “Seam,” referencing the lyrics, “On this seam I will dream.” An earlier version with the old title and alternate lyrics was later released as part of the deluxe Gish Reissue.

Produced by the then-obscure grunge icon, Butch Vig, “Suffer” holds the distinction of being the only song on the album played in ¾ time. The unique guitar tones coupled with Corgan’s inventive song structure have held the test of time, acting as one more pillar of support that holds Gish up as a classic rock album.

songs.full_title: Knights of Malta by The Smashing Pumpkins
songs.title: Knights of Malta

description.plain:
“Knights of Malta” was the third song released off the Pumpkins' 10th studio album, Shiny and Oh So Bright, Vol. I / LP: No Past. No Future. No Sun, after “Solara” and “Silvery Sometimes (Ghosts)”.

In contrast to the previously released tracks of new material in 2018, “Knights of Malta” differs from the band’s classic sound by using a choir, as well as boasting catchier pop sensibilities.

Like the rest of the album, the song was recorded by legendary producer Rick Rubin at Shangri-La Studios.

Would-be title track to the multi-platinum Siamese Dream album, the song only appeared as the B-side to the 7-inch version of the “Disarm” single.

songs.title: Starla

description.plain:
From the Pisces Iscariot liner notes:

“my friend aneta still says to me that this song should have been on siamese dream. but back again to that no record 2x rule. this was recorded at the same time as plume, and was also intended to be a demo, but we needed b-sides for our pretty XXXXXXXXXNX worthless i am one u.k. single (the dark continent) so in a way plume and starla were their own single if that make makes any sense at all. recorded over time, or recorded at two different sessions, one for vocals and solos and one for drums, etc,.another song with lyrics written at the last second. i wrote the middle part on the back of an envelope–serve yourself no one else can do for you like you and no one else fails like me but in my eyes i i burn alive no more words just you and i high in the the sky–some of my favourite lyrics. better that i did not care solo played at 7am. listen for the police car going by.

i met this girl in dallas when we were on tour with the chili peppa’s and that was where i got the idea for the name for the song because when she said her name i thought wow, what a great title for a song. 2 ¼ years later i run into this same girl at a party and i say did you hear that song we recorded using your name, starla? and she said, no my name is darla but hey starla, darla whatever it doesn’t matter, so there you go. never trust a girl who ends up with well i can’t say."

Produced by Kerry Brown.

songs.title: Soothe

description.plain:
“Soothe” is a stripped down acoustic demo recorded by a lone Billy Corgan in his Chicago apartment. One can actually hear traffic on the streets below with a close listen.

The song acts as the opening track for the compilation album, Pisces Iscariot. “Soothe” was originally released as one of five B-sides on the “Disarm” single, which is technically closer to an EP.

songs.full_title: Appels + Oranjes by The Smashing Pumpkins
songs.title: Appels + Oranjes

description.plain:
“Appels + Oranjes” touches on the age-old subject of metaphysics; a branch of philosophy that explores reality.  Is reality what we perceive in our day-to-day experiences or is there something else to it that is beyond the experience of our sense organs?  All of the great thinkers in both the Western and Eastern world have postulated the latter.

In essence, the idea behind “Appels + Oranjes” is to ask a question that, if answered, would not only change the way you view the world and all that is, but it would force you to reevaluate your own concept of self.  Historically, this line of thinking has been received by the public as somewhat depressing and even Nihilistic.  Corgan is much more optimistic.  He begins by asking this ancient question, but then he follows up with another question; challenging the familiar response.

The lyrics imply that even if true reality is completely unfathomable to human beings, it may be a good thing.  After all, why are we so desperate to hold onto our concept of reality when the vast majority suffers under this reality?  It may even be an antidote to the human condition.  Perhaps all the confusion and division and destructive patterns we see would finally come to a halt if only we could solve the riddle of reality.

songs.full_title: Glass and the Ghost Children by The Smashing Pumpkins
songs.title: Glass and the Ghost Children

description.plain:
“Glass and the Ghost Children” formally introduces Glass, the protagonist of Machina.  The Ghost Children are his fanbase of which he struggles to communicate directly with.

Glass himself is an exaggerated version of Billy Corgan.  Corgan was aware yet uneasy regarding the notion some fans had of him.  Namely, that he was some sort of rock and roll prophet capable of saving the soul of the listener.  Glass is the embodiment of that idea.

I thought it would be easier to assume a character to say what I really wanted to say and express what I really wanted to express."

songs.full_title: This Time by The Smashing Pumpkins
songs.title: This Time

description.plain:
“This Time” is a song about breakup. While the lyrics could refer to the end of a romantic relationship, they most likely prefigure the split of The Smashing Pumpkins themselves. At the time of writing, bassist D'arcy Wretzky had already left the band and it would not be long before the remaining members would part ways.

This latter interpretation is supported by the use of collective phrases like “my friends” and “we’ll cry as all”, as well as references to drug use (which dogged some members of the band).

Machina/The Machines of God was originally intended as a multi-part concept album, but Billy Corgan himself has expressed difficulty in pinpointing the exact nature of this narrative.

Whatever their true inspiration, the lyrics are sufficiently ambiguous to effectively express the sorrow of a good relationship thwarted by circumstance; that something beautiful will be lost forever.

songs.full_title: The Boy by The Smashing Pumpkins
songs.title: The Boy

description.plain:
Originally released as one of the B-Sides for the “1979” single, guitarist James Iha described this song to Guitar World in 1997 as…“a New Wave song.”  As he continues the interview, he speaks more about how the music for this tune was created:

[I used] the power-pop Jazzmaster with a warped neck that looks cool but isn’t really good to play. There’s also this funny guitar-drum break in the middle of the song where I hang a chord and use the whammy bar. Flood [Producer for the majority of Smashing Pumpkins tracks.  Flood has also produced for many notable rock artists such as Nine Inch Nails, Depeche Mode, and PJ Harvey as well as holding the executive producer title for the iconic U2 album, Joshua Tree] liked this song but it just didn’t fit the album."

Fitting that this song would land as a b-side to “1979” given that it marks another early departure for the Pumpkins from music that is reliant on guitars.  Like “1979,” this song relies on processed vocals to create a general ambiance.  Not only that, but the drum sequence is identical to that song.

Below you can see some of the original artwork for the single.

songs.full_title: The Tale of Dusty and Pistol Pete by The Smashing Pumpkins
songs.title: The Tale of Dusty and Pistol Pete
songs.title_with_featured: The Tale of Dusty and Pistol Pete

description.plain:
“The Tale of Dusty and Pistol Pete,” like much of Adore, combines electronic music with something akin to folk rock.

The story is one of murder. After Pistol Pete kills his female lover, Dusty, she passes on to the other side without realizing it, thus becoming a ghost. Still very much in love with Pistol Pete, “she calls to him” constantly.

Irony lies in that by attempting to be rid of her, Pistol Pete instead ensures that this woman will haunt him for an eternity.

songs.full_title: Set the Ray to Jerry by The Smashing Pumpkins
songs.title: Set the Ray to Jerry

description.plain:
“Set the Ray to Jerry” was released as a b-side to the power pop hit, “1979.”  Similar to “1979,” “Jerry” doesn’t rely on guitars but rather uses them as an effect to accentuate the rest of the instrumentation.  At the root, “Jerry” is a deceivingly simple song with a guitar melody consisting of two notes.

While “Jerry” is a b-side, it has become a definitive Pumpkins staple.  In 2012, Rolling Stone ran a feature in which readers rated their favorite SP tracks.  It ranked at #19, described as “top-shelf and "beautiful.  Slant Magazine ranked the song at #14, praising "Corgan’s ear for crafting simple melodies.”

An obvious highlight comes from drummer Jimmy Chamberlin, making good use of his jazz background to take a subdued soundscape and slow tempo to another level.  While many drummers might take a more simple approach, Jimmy gets busy, using his skills to infuse surprising energy into this down-tempo piece.

songs.title: Tiberius

description.plain:
Monuments opens with “Tiberius”, the third single from the album. With an instrumental introduction similar to the bands smash-hit “Today”, the first guitar lays down a simple lead before another guitar with big distortion along with the drums and bass join in to create a powerful sound.

As mentioned in a Rolling Stone article, Corgan describes this song as sounding exactly like the title and tells us to “…Imagine marching hordes.”

songs.full_title: Infinite Sadness by The Smashing Pumpkins
songs.title: Infinite Sadness

description.plain:
“Infinite Sadness,” originally titled “Melon Collie,” is an instrumental composed by Billy Corgan and recorded sometime between December 1992 and March 1993, along with the majority of the songs that would later make up  Pisces Iscariot and the iconic Siamese Dream album.

The song was originally slated to be the last track on the double album, Melon Collie and the Infinite Sadness. While it was cut from the CD and cassette releases, it was featured on the vinyl release along with another bonus track, “Tonite Reprise.”

A portion of “Infinite Sadness” can be heard during the outro on “Thru the Eyes of Ruby.”

songs.full_title: Purple Blood by The Smashing Pumpkins
songs.title: Purple Blood

description.plain: “Purple Blood” explores the contrast of soft, twinkling acoustics and thundering guitar, ultimately representing the duality and contradictions of unwavering humanity through tribulation and dark, devoted love. Reaching from the abyss with a hand cloaked in shadow, it pulls one in, against better judgement, with striking declarations– wrapping the listener in intense melodies of crimson and violet ribbon. Over it all, sharp, confessing vocals. This track is nothing short of raw, addictive, and plutonian.

songs.full_title: Frail and Bedazzled by The Smashing Pumpkins
songs.title: Frail and Bedazzled

description.plain:
A high energy rock song charged with the same electricity heard in the now-classics such as “Rocket” and “Cherub Rock”.  The song is now a fan-favorite, and was performed live over 30 times in 2011 alone, 17 years after it was released.

“Frail and Bedazzled” was recorded sometime between December 1992 and March 1993 in Marietta, Georgia as part of the recording sessions that would eventually become the basis for the Siamese Dream album.

By his own admission, Corgan wrote these lyrics during an extended period of time in which he lived in a parking garage despite his recent successes that came with the release of the Pumpkin’s debut album Gish. Fast forward to the recording of this track and Corgan takes to sleeping on D'arcy Wretzky’s floor.

songs.full_title: My Blue Heaven by The Smashing Pumpkins
songs.title: My Blue Heaven

description.plain:
“My Blue Heaven” was written in 1924 by Walter Donaldson, with lyrics by George A. Whiting. Sung by many, the song was made popular by crooner Gene Austin, and was a number one hit for 13 weeks in 1928. Selling over five million copies, the recording became one of the best selling singles of all time.

The lyrics of the song portray the familiar ideal of the elusive American Dream through its description of independence and having a peaceful refuge away from the chaos of the city. Although poetic in nature, the lyrics are still very appealing to multitudes of individuals, evoking clear and beautiful imagery.

songs.title: Cherry

description.plain:
“Cherry” originally appeared as a B side on the “1979” single, taken from the multi-platinum Mellon Collie and the Infinite Sadness album.  In an interview with Guitar World in 1997, Billy shared his thoughts on the song:

Of all the B-sides, this song is probably my biggest regret. I never spent as much time on it as it probably deserved, with this version showing very little improvement from the demo. This one probably should have made the album.

songs.full_title: Birch Grove by The Smashing Pumpkins
songs.title: Birch Grove

description.plain: “You know, I’m 53 and my kids are 5 and 2. I look at them and think ‘are they gonna grow up without me?’. So I wanted to write this song as almost like a card from dad, like a roadmap, something maybe only they would understand. If you listen to this song when I’m gone- this is who your father was, this is what your father thought about, not what other people are gonna tell you who I was or what I thought about. This is what I’m actually thinking about.” – William Patrick Corgan on the Stern Show

description.plain:
The original core of the band, Billy Corgan and James Iha record one of the first tracks ever created under the name The Smashing Pumpkins.



This was recorded by the original duo in 1988 in Billy’s father’s house using a simple drum machine, two years before the band’s first single, “I Am One” would be released.

songs.title: Wyttch

description.plain: “Wyttch,” suitably released on “Hallow’s Eve” (Oct. 30th) with the accompanying music video released on Friday the 13th (Nov. 13), is an unflinching and sly occult track. Snarling vocals, resounding, deep guitar, and references to witchcraft, astrology, ritualistic practices, and ancient myth open up the very Gates of Hades to pack a classic Smashing Pumpkins punch.

songs.full_title: Pale Horse by The Smashing Pumpkins
songs.title: Pale Horse

description.plain:
Corgan told Music Radar a lot about the instrumentation to this song, drawing a heavy contrast between the old Pumpkins albums and the newer ones:

This was one of those where you have a good riff, and you say, ‘I’m going to write a song around it’…you don’t want to get too tricky [as it takes away the] hypnotic effect…In old Pumpkins ideology, if you started with that riff, the song would get bigger and louder. In this ideology, it actually gets smaller, and that’s how you get the dynamic back up."

Corgan, notoriously enigmatic with his lyrics, makes no mention of the fact that the Pale Horse is a name found in the Book of Revelations, which details Armageddon.  There are four horses that represent the end times.  The Pale Horse is associated with death.



The Pale Horse can be seen on the far left

On a video recorded during an Oceania recording session, Billy refers to “Pale Horse” as being about “mia madre” (spanish for “my mother”). After her death in 1996, his mother was famously immortalized in Adore’s “For Martha”.

songs.full_title: One and All (We Are) by The Smashing Pumpkins
songs.title: One and All (We Are)

description.plain:
“One And All” is the second single and fourth track off Smashing Pumpkin’s 2014 album, Monuments To An Elegy.

More than a few fans have observed a marked similarity in the primary guitar riff to “The Viper,” a much older bit originally found of the 666 Tapes, a noncommercial video piece documenting Corgan and producer Flood working through the creative process of Melon Collie and the Infinite Sadness.

Lead singer/guitarist Billy Corgan explained:

I basically sang the whole song the first time I wrote it. It had written itself.

This song is significantly harder than the album’s first single, “Being Beige.”

songs.title: Pennies

description.plain:
This not very well known Smashing Pumpkins song was first released as a B-Side to their hit single “Zero” which later was added to their third album “Mellon Collie and the Infinite Sadness”. The song was later added by the Smashing Pumpkins to their collection album “Rarities and B-Sides” and then once again added to another compilation album “Aeroplane Flies High”.

The song is quite self explanatory in its lyrics. When boiled down it’s a love song about an ex-girlfriend who Billy never fully got over, and seeks to find her in other women.

songs.title: Pissant

description.plain:
With no attempt to make this song pretty, the fuzzed out guitar riffs along with Chamberlin’s aggressive treatment of the drums make this a standout track.

The first lyric, “Got me a raygun” almost seems to foreshadow the coming guitar solo, which sounds as if Corgan somehow traded in his guitar for a futuristic weapon.

Despite its B-side status, “Pissant” has been universally praised by critics.  It’s been described as “An enjoyable grunge groover”, a “colossal electric odyssey”, a “5 out of 5:  Loud, mindless fun, with the teenage angst we all love so much.”, and the list goes on.

As Corgan states in the liner notes below, “Pissant” was recorded live, a rarity for the Pumpkins or any major label band for that matter.  Written and recorded with the intention of being included on Siamese Dream, the song instead appeared as a B-side on the “Cherub Rock” single.

An early demo version of this song exists, featuring completely different lyrics but with a nearly identical musical arrangement.

songs.full_title: Dancing in the Moonlight by The Smashing Pumpkins
songs.title: Dancing in the Moonlight

description.plain:
Corgan artfully covers the classic hit single of the same title by Thin Lizzy.  Although the same chords and vocal melodies are used, the overall effect of the record is much different.

The original is very upbeat and fueled by those energized electric guitar riffs we’ve come to associate with ‘70’s era rock 'n’ roll, whereas the Smashing Pumpkins'  song sounds much more like an acoustic ballad.  Beautifully dark, brooding, and full of passion, this song is an excellent addition to the Pumpkins expansive collection of rare songs.

songs.full_title: Marquis in Spades by The Smashing Pumpkins
songs.title: Marquis in Spades

description.plain:
Originally released as a B-Side for the smash hit, “Zero,”, “Marquis in Spades” falls into the hardrock side of the Pumpkins; very fitting for the Zero EP.

Corgan broods angrily over a heavy and ominous guitar track, using his signature whisper-to-scream vocals to further the dark tone of this composition.

songs.title: Anaise!

description.plain:
“Anaise!” holds the unique distinction of being the only song on Monuments To An Elegy with punctuation in the title.

Next from the random pile was ANAIS: a riff I’d toyed with on the last SP touring cycle but hadn’t gotten far with; too busy I guess. But in the first round of demo-making I was able to turn the busy-body riff into a shoegazer wash which when laced with big, simpler guitars feels fatal. – Billy Corgan

songs.full_title: Slow Dawn by The Smashing Pumpkins
songs.title: Slow Dawn

description.plain:
Originally released as part of the Machina II album, “Slow Dawn” is yet another piece of the Glass and the Machines of God narrative. The lyrics are written in the first person through the eyes of our protagonist, Zero/Glass.

When compared to the majority of the songs found on Machina II, “Slow Dawn” gives the impression of acceptance and relative peace. The guitar solo in particular is a lifting of spirit, full of optimism.

We can see this turn to optimism in the lyrics as well, with “the songbirds all around.” For this reason, it’s very plausible that the song belongs towards the end of the narrative, after Glass lost all control only to eventually regain it, rejoining the world below (“the midnight people washing down here”), and embracing life for what it is.

songs.full_title: That's the Way (My Love Is) by The Smashing Pumpkins
songs.title: That’s the Way (My Love Is)

description.plain:
The second single off Zeitgeist was initially met with negative reviews, with critics engaging in endless comparisons to their ‘classic’ songs.  In a fashion all too familiar to the Smashing Pumpkins, these opinions have slowly turned positive.  Spin Magazine now considers this to be one of the greatest Pumpkin tracks ever released (well, in the top 20 anyway).

For reasons unknown, Paris Hilton appears in the music video in an odd fashion.  She shows up briefly and discreetly, like a flicker on a television screen.  The video is set in the future, with Corgan chasing after the object of his affection.

https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=PDtMWRWWNwM

songs.full_title: Pastichio Medley by The Smashing Pumpkins
songs.title: Pastichio Medley

description.plain:
Released on the Zero EP, “Pastichio Medley” isn’t really as much of a song as it is a collection of short instrumental segments.

“Pastichio Medley” contains over 73 separate songs (each around 10 seconds long), a testament to just how much work went into the creating of the Pumpkins' magnum opus, Mellon Collie and the Infinite Sadness.  Not only were dozens of outtakes released as b-sides, but as we can see here, many musical ideas never made it to be a b-side, regardless of the amount of work that went into each piece.

songs.title: Blue

description.plain:
From the Lull EP, later included on B-sides collection “Pisces Iscariot.”  Here are Billy’s notes from that album insert:

“blue is the only gish outtake represented here. from the lull single! viva lull and remastered by our man howie for yer listening pleasure. yet another sad happy song from the o'corrigan file. i thought about using an acoustic version of the song for this album, but it seemed silly to have a different version of an unknown song. maybe someday. on tour forever, blue i lay with you this velvet morning stay with me for a while a million yeses and no’s strewn across 6 long years. but it all adds up to something even if you are not quite sure of what that is.”
